title: How to Demonstrate the Cooling of Expanding Gas

steps.headline: Connect 2 insulated containers.
steps.description: One container will be used to house the gas before the expansion. The second container will be empty and provide additional volume for the gas to occupy as it expands. Use a valved hose or pipe to connect these containers so that the contents of the connected containers can be closed off from one another.

steps.headline: Pressurize the first container.
steps.description: Check the valve between the containers to confirm that it is closed. Use a cylinder of compressed air to force air into the first container. Pressurize the container to approximately 1.5 atm. Use a barometer to check the pressure.

steps.headline: Evacuate the second container.
steps.description: Ensure that the valve between the containers remains closed. Use a vacuum pump to evacuate gas from the second container. It will not be possible to remove all gas from the container, but you should make sure that the container is approximately 0.1 atm. A barometer can be used to determine the negative pressure (vacuum).

steps.headline: Take initial temperature readings of the gas.
steps.description: After you have pressurized the first container, let the gas sit undisturbed for approximately 5 minutes. This should be sufficient time for the temperature to equilibrate and provide an accurate reading. Take a temperature reading of the gas inside the container and record it as your initial temperature. Using a container with a lid or stopcock (a valve that regulates the flow of the gas) is ideal. This way you can insert the thermometer into the stopcock to measure the temperature without letting gas escape.

steps.headline: Allow the gas to expand into both containers.
steps.description: Open the valve. The gas will move from the high pressure container to the low pressure container until it reaches equilibrium. This is known as expansion.

steps.headline: Take a final temperature reading.
steps.description: Once the gas has expanded, take a second temperature reading. Record this reading as your final temperature. Notice that this temperature should be lower than your initial temperature.

steps.headline: Consider the ideal gas law.
steps.description:
The ideal gas law describes the behavior of a hypothetical gas in which molecules do not interact with each other, except for totally elastic collisions. Elastic collisions will result in no net energy change. According to this law, if volume increases and pressure is held constant, temperature would increase. Thus, it is clear that real gases do not behave in an “ideal” way. The equation describing this behavior is PV=nR:


P = Pressure
V = Volume
n = Moles of Gas
R = Ideal Gas Constant
T = Temperature

steps.headline: Realize that gas molecules interact with each other.
steps.description: The primary difference between ideal and real gases is that real gases have molecules that interact in inelastic ways. That is to say, the energetic state of the molecules changes based on how they interact with each other. This means that heat will rise in a smaller volume of gas (due to more collisions between molecules) and will fall when the same amount of gas occupies a larger volume.

steps.headline: Keep in mind that a truly adiabatic system does not exist.
steps.description: It is important to realize that adiabatic conditions are theoretical. There is no such thing as a perfectly insulated system, and there will be some heat exchange with the outside universe. That said, if measurements are taken quickly enough, that exchange can be negligible for this experiment.

Mimicking Adiabatic Conditions Connect 2 insulated containers. One container will be used to house the gas before the expansion. The second container will be empty and provide additional volume for the gas to occupy as it expands. Use a valved hose or pipe to connect these containers so that the contents of the connected containers can be closed off from one another. Pressurize the first container. Check the valve between the containers to confirm that it is closed. Use a cylinder of compressed air to force air into the first container. Pressurize the container to approximately 1.5 atm. Use a barometer to check the pressure. Evacuate the second container. Ensure that the valve between the containers remains closed. Use a vacuum pump to evacuate gas from the second container. It will not be possible to remove all gas from the container, but you should make sure that the container is approximately 0.1 atm. A barometer can be used to determine the negative pressure (vacuum). Carrying out the Experiment Take initial temperature readings of the gas. After you have pressurized the first container, let the gas sit undisturbed for approximately 5 minutes. This should be sufficient time for the temperature to equilibrate and provide an accurate reading. Take a temperature reading of the gas inside the container and record it as your initial temperature. Using a container with a lid or stopcock (a valve that regulates the flow of the gas) is ideal. This way you can insert the thermometer into the stopcock to measure the temperature without letting gas escape. Allow the gas to expand into both containers. Open the valve. The gas will move from the high pressure container to the low pressure container until it reaches equilibrium. This is known as expansion. Take a final temperature reading. Once the gas has expanded, take a second temperature reading. Record this reading as your final temperature. Notice that this temperature should be lower than your initial temperature. Understanding the Results Consider the ideal gas law. The ideal gas law describes the behavior of a hypothetical gas in which molecules do not interact with each other, except for totally elastic collisions. Elastic collisions will result in no net energy change. According to this law, if volume increases and pressure is held constant, temperature would increase. Thus, it is clear that real gases do not behave in an “ideal” way. The equation describing this behavior is PV=nR:


P = Pressure
V = Volume
n = Moles of Gas
R = Ideal Gas Constant
T = Temperature Realize that gas molecules interact with each other. The primary difference between ideal and real gases is that real gases have molecules that interact in inelastic ways. That is to say, the energetic state of the molecules changes based on how they interact with each other. This means that heat will rise in a smaller volume of gas (due to more collisions between molecules) and will fall when the same amount of gas occupies a larger volume. Keep in mind that a truly adiabatic system does not exist. It is important to realize that adiabatic conditions are theoretical. There is no such thing as a perfectly insulated system, and there will be some heat exchange with the outside universe. That said, if measurements are taken quickly enough, that exchange can be negligible for this experiment.
